questions.article: Many readers both young and old enjoyed and ______ Meg Medina’s book Merci Suárez Changes Gears, so it was not a surprise when the Association for Library Service to Children awarded it the Newbery Medal in 2019.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

questions.article: One challenge of generating electricity from ocean waves is that wave power isn’t ______: it varies in unpredictable ways that pose technological and planning problems for electricity generation.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

questions.article:
The following text is from Jhumpa Lahiri’s 2003 novel The Namesake. Gogol, a child, is at a beach in Massachusetts with his father.

He watches his father raise a kite within minutes into the wind, so high that Gogol must tip his head back in order to see, a rippling speck against the sky. The wind whips around their ears, turning their faces cold.

©2003 by Jhumpa Lahiri
questions.question: As used in the text, what does the word “tip” most nearly mean?

questions.article: Radar and sonar can detect objects or people through walls, but they are too costly for consumer use. Researchers Fadel Adib and Dina Katabi have shown, however, that there may be a comparatively ______ alternative: small changes to the Wi-Fi technology used in smartphones can give users a cheap way to count people or even identify their gestures through walls.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

questions.article: Some pieces of music might have many ______—the compositions of Harriet Ware can potentially be explained in as many ways as there are people to listen to them—and so as long as a listener’s reasoning isn’t absurd or the result of inattention, it is difficult to justify the claim that the listener has misunderstood the piece.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

questions.article: Were penguins always flightless? Theresa Cole and her team argue that penguins could fly at some point, but that they lost that ability more than 60 million years ago as they adapted to marine life. After examining various penguin fossils and genetic information, the researchers concluded that over time penguins developed underwater vision, blood oxygenation, and bone density better suited for swimming than flying. Thus, environmental conditions might have driven penguins to change from flyers to swimmers.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the function of the underlined sentence in the text as a whole?

options.name: A
options.content: It provides an answer to the question in the previous sentence.

options.name: B
options.content: It contradicts a description in the sentence that follows.

options.name: C
options.content: It notes that the question in the previous sentence has not been researched.

options.name: D
options.content: It defines a scientific term used in the sentence that follows.

questions.correct: It provides an answer to the question in the previous sentence.

questions.article:
The following text is from Anne Spencer’s 1922 poem “Translation.”

We trekked into a far country,
My friend and I.
Our deeper content was never spoken,
But each knew all the other said.
He told me how calm his soul was laid
By the lack of anvil and strife.
“The wooing kestrel,” I said, “mutes his mating-note
To please the harmony of this sweet silence.”
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: It lists the sights that the speaker and her friend encounter while on a long hike.

options.name: B
options.content: It conveys the speaker’s awareness that she is both attracted to and repelled by nature.

options.name: C
options.content: It describes differences between the speaker’s translation of a literary work and another translation of the same work.

options.name: D
options.content: It depicts a feeling of unspoken connection between the speaker and her friend.

questions.correct: It depicts a feeling of unspoken connection between the speaker and her friend.

questions.article:
Text 1

From about 985 CE to the early 1400s, when they mysteriously abandoned the region, Norse settlers occupied part of Greenland. Many researchers cite increasingly lower temperatures to explain why the Norse fled. The researchers reason that the Norse settlers arrived in the region while the climate was warm and were able to remain there until temperatures declined during the Little Ice Age, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries.

Text 2

William Daniels, Boyang Zhao, and colleagues analyzed sediment samples from a lake in Greenland close to the Norse settlement. This allowed them to reconstruct the area’s climate history. The researchers found no evidence of substantial temperature changes during the settlement period. They argue that instead the region experienced a persistent drought, which played a more important role in forcing the Norse out of the area than did increasingly lower temperatures.
questions.question: Both texts discuss research on which topic?

options.name: A
options.content: The first artifacts found at a Norse settlement

options.name: B
options.content: The abandonment of the Norse settlement in Greenland

options.name: C
options.content: The history of drought in Greenland

options.name: D
options.content: The causes of the Little Ice Age

questions.correct: The abandonment of the Norse settlement in Greenland

questions.article: During the World War II era, some Mexican American women adopted a striking new look called pachuca style. They wore altered men’s jackets or zoot suits (wide-legged, long-coated suits) and dramatic makeup, and they combed their hair into high, rounded shapes. Some people criticized pachuca style, saying it was dangerous and women should dress traditionally. But historians see things differently. They see pachuca style as a form of rebellion against the era’s rigid social expectations for women. They say that it showed a desire for self-expression and freedom on the part of women who adopted the style.
questions.question: According to the text, how do historians view pachuca style?

options.name: A
options.content: They think that pachuca style was similar to other fashion trends that different groups of women adopted in the same period.

options.name: B
options.content: They think that pachuca style was celebrated because it enabled some Mexican American women to show their support for the United States during World War II.

options.name: C
options.content: They think that pachuca style was such a popular trend that it continues to influence fashion in the United States to the present day.

options.name: D
options.content: They think that pachuca style was a way for some Mexican American women to express themselves and resist strict social expectations.

questions.correct: They think that pachuca style was a way for some Mexican American women to express themselves and resist strict social expectations.

questions.article: Community science involves professional scientists collaborating with members of the public to study a topic. This approach to research can promote community engagement by building youth confidence in the sciences. It’s also very effective because it greatly increases the amount of data that can be collected, such as when biologist Abbigail Merrill and colleagues studied how butterfly color relates to flower choice and used findings reported by hundreds of students and community members in northwestern Arkansas.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main idea of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: A community science approach can increase youth confidence in learning science and generate large amounts of data, benefiting both communities and researchers.

options.name: B
options.content: A community science approach can benefit communities by increasing youth confidence in learning science, but it’s less likely to help researchers obtain accurate data.

options.name: C
options.content: Abbigail Merrill and colleagues used a community science approach in their butterfly research and were surprised at the effect this had on youth confidence in learning science.

options.name: D
options.content: A community science approach allows researchers to collect significantly more data even though it’s unlikely to have much of an effect on youth confidence in learning science.

questions.correct: A community science approach can increase youth confidence in learning science and generate large amounts of data, benefiting both communities and researchers.

questions.article: The US Department of Agriculture’s Fruit and Tree Nuts Outlook is a document that covers a variety of subjects, from the influence of changing climate on agricultural production to the effect of stinkbug damage on pear crops. A student studying agricultural economics is consulting a graph in the document that shows the prices for which several types of nuts have been sold by growers in the United States over four growing seasons from 2016 to 2020. The student wishes to determine in which season hazelnuts reached their highest price. Consulting the graph, the student finds that this season was the ______
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses data from the graph to complete the statement?

questions.article: A student is writing a research paper on the history of irrigation in the southwestern United States, situating the development of the Bear River Reservoir (a man-made body of water created in Amador County, California, in 1900) in a larger historical context. The student claims that some modern-day irrigation methods used in southwestern states, such as California, Arizona, and New Mexico, have a lineage that long predates the completion of the Bear River Reservoir.
questions.question: Which quotation from a historian best supports the student’s claim?

options.name: A
options.content: “In the decades following the Second World War, irrigation of arid areas for agriculture increased to such a degree that it now accounts for roughly 70% of the world’s water usage.”

options.name: B
options.content: “The importance of the development of irrigation infrastructure in the American Southwest today cannot be overstated, since it is the most common means of conveying water for food production.”

options.name: C
options.content: “Sprinkler irrigation systems, which were developed in the late 20th century, are a convenient technique of irrigating that makes use of machinery in order to spray water in all directions. Many areas of the Southwestern United States are currently irrigated by this method.”

options.name: D
options.content: “The irrigation system developed by the Hohokam people in what is now central Arizona in the 7th century CE was simple but made use of hydraulic engineering design principles that are still utilized by today’s engineers.”

questions.correct: “The irrigation system developed by the Hohokam people in what is now central Arizona in the 7th century CE was simple but made use of hydraulic engineering design principles that are still utilized by today’s engineers.”

questions.article: Eastern Maine’s Washington County is among the most rural counties in the United States: the US Census Bureau classified it as 92.4% rural in 2010. Researchers have struggled to recruit residents of counties like Washington for inclusion in studies. Noting this problem, Melissa Valerio and colleagues tested two recruitment techniques in rural counties: purposive sampling, in which researchers contact many potential participants who have the characteristics desired for a given study, and snowball sampling, in which researchers recruit a few people with the desired characteristics and ask them to recruit additional participants. Valerio and colleagues concluded that the latter approach may be superior.
questions.question: Which finding, if true, would most directly support Valerio and colleagues’ conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: Snowball sampling yielded significantly more participants with the desired characteristics than purposive sampling did.

options.name: B
options.content: Snowball sampling yielded significantly more participants than would be expected if researchers contacted people without regard to those people’s characteristics.

options.name: C
options.content: Participants recruited through snowball sampling were more likely to have taken part in previous studies than were participants recruited through purposive sampling.

options.name: D
options.content: Most participants recruited through snowball sampling had different characteristics than the initial participants who recruited them.

questions.correct: Snowball sampling yielded significantly more participants with the desired characteristics than purposive sampling did.

questions.article: Louis-Ferdinand Céline’s 1932 novel Journey to the End of the Night contains elements drawn from Céline’s own life—there are many parallels between the experiences of the novel’s protagonist, Ferdinand Bardamu, and those of Céline—and as a result Journey to the End of the Night is regularly described as an autobiographical novel. This characterization can be useful, but it also presents drawbacks in terms of how the work is perceived, as it may lead readers to believe that Céline merely fictionalized true events, which, in an artistic field where creativity and inventiveness are prized, can suggest that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: Journey to the End of the Night is less of an imaginative achievement than it actually is.

options.name: B
options.content: the real-world counterparts of other characters in Journey to the End of the Night are hard to identify.

options.name: C
options.content: Céline should not have claimed that Journey to the End of the Night is based on real events.

options.name: D
options.content: critics disagree about whether Journey to the End of the Night shows greater originality than works

questions.correct: Journey to the End of the Night is less of an imaginative achievement than it actually is.

questions.article: If an animal has been extinct for a long time, how can scientists learn what color it was? One group of scientists came up with a possible answer. When the scientists examined the fossilized feather of an extinct bird, they found melanosomes in it. Melanosomes produce pigment, or grains of color, inside cells. Because melanosomes are shaped differently depending on which colors they produce, the scientists hypothesized that they could ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: show how melanosomes can be found in fossils belonging to animals from other extinct species.

options.name: B
options.content: determine the colors of the bird based on the appearance of the melanosomes in the feather.

options.name: C
options.content: explain why the melanosomes in the feather were so well preserved.

options.name: D
options.content: identify the colors of extinct animals whose fossils lack melanosomes.

questions.correct: determine the colors of the bird based on the appearance of the melanosomes in the feather.

questions.article: In recent years, architects have heightened their focus on developing eco-conscious and sustainable buildings, as exemplified by Wendy House, a structure conceived by Earthscape Studio. One way to accomplish this goal is through biophilic design, which seeks to augment occupants’ emotional and physical well-being by establishing a coherent relationship among the building, nature, and human biology. Along with using ecologically sensitive construction materials, biophilic designs incorporate organic or biomorphic forms and textures. Curves, therefore, are common design features because they ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: are reminiscent of the arcing and contours found among plants and animals.

options.name: B
options.content: are common in building designs in many different regions and cultures.

options.name: C
options.content: prioritize practicality over the personal aesthetic preferences of the architect.

options.name: D
options.content: emphasize the aesthetic distinction between nature and architecture.

questions.correct: are reminiscent of the arcing and contours found among plants and animals.

questions.article: We came to see the famous artworks inside the State Hermitage Museum in Russia, yet the building itself ______ us the most. The building, we later learned, had been designed by Italian architect Francesco Rastrelli in 1762.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: In 2003, actor Keith David voiced the character Despero in the television show Justice League. Throughout his career, David has acted in everything from commercials to Broadway musicals. However, ______ the most recognition for voice acting.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: African American nurse Ann Bradford Stokes was one of thousands of nurses who provided medical care to soldiers during the American Civil War. Like many of ______ nurses, Stokes was later commended for her work.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: Many ranching terms come from Spanish. The word “mustang” (a wild horse) comes from the Spanish word mesteñas, and “rodeo” (a ______ comes from rodear. This is because the first Anglo, African, and Native American cattle ranchers in the southwestern US learned the trade from Spanish-speaking Mexican vaqueros, or cowboys.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: Exemplars of Stigler’s law ______ there is Cartesian duality; in mathematics, Euler’s formula; and in fluid mechanics, the Reynolds number. All the aforementioned share the trait of being named after individuals who were not their initial discoverers or inventors.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

questions.article: KBFT is a Native-run radio station broadcasting from the Bois Forte Band of Chippewa’s lands in Minnesota. In 2004, Loris Taylor wanted to make sure that stations like KBFT continued to thrive. ______ she founded Native Public Media, a support system for Native radio stations that now includes around sixty stations.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

questions.article: As anthropologist Cristina Grasseni explains, with the rise in demand for artisanal cheeses claiming to be typical of specific Italian regions, such as Mozzarella di Bufala Campana cheese from Molise, came the need to guarantee the veracity of such claims to consumers. ______ the European Union established DOP status, a label certifying that the cheese was made according to the region’s local traditions.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

questions.article: Giovanna Giardino is a space scientist who works on the James Webb Space Telescope, or JWST. Thanks in part to Giardino’s contributions, the telescope is now positioned near the Sun-Earth L2 Lagrange point, almost one million miles beyond Earth’s orbit. ______ the JWST’s predecessor, the Hubble Telescope, is only about 340 miles above Earth’s surface.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Yukon River is in North America.
  • It ranks No. 23 among the longest rivers in the world.
  • It is 3,185 kilometers long.
  • The Rhine River is in Europe.
  • It ranks No. 129 among the longest rivers in the world.
  • It is 1,233 kilometers long.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize a similarity between the two rivers. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: The Yukon River, ranked No. 23 among the longest rivers in the world, is 3,185 kilometers long.

options.name: B
options.content: At 1,233 kilometers long, the Rhine River ranks No. 129 among the longest rivers in the world.

options.name: C
options.content: The Rhine River is located in Europe, and it is 1,233 kilometers long.

options.name: D
options.content: The Yukon and Rhine rivers are both ranked among the longest in the world.

questions.correct: The Yukon and Rhine rivers are both ranked among the longest in the world.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Don’t Cry Over Spilt Milk is a 2021 sculpture by British artist Eve De Haan.
  • It is crafted from blue neon lighting that spells out the title phrase (“don’t cry over spilt milk”).
  • Ginger is a 2023 sculpture by Japanese artist Rikako Kawauchi.
  • It is crafted from pink neon lighting that forms an abstract squiggle shape.
questions.question: The student wants to emphasize a difference between the two sculptures. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: Don’t Cry Over Spilt Milk, like Ginger, is a sculpture.

options.name: B
options.content: Both De Haan’s and Kawauchi’s sculptures are crafted from neon lighting.

options.name: C
options.content: Eve De Haan and Rikako Kawauchi are artists who have used neon in their sculptures.

options.name: D
options.content: Unlike De Haan’s sculpture, which spells out a phrase, Kawauchi’s is an abstract squiggle shape.

questions.correct: Unlike De Haan’s sculpture, which spells out a phrase, Kawauchi’s is an abstract squiggle shape.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • The Paralympic Games are a series of international sporting events involving athletes with an impairment.
  • A gold medal indicates that an athlete finished in first place.
  • Frank Höfle competed as a Paralympic cross-country skier from 1988 to 2006.
  • He won seventeen medals, ten of which were gold.
  • Mayumi Narita competed as a Paralympic swimmer from 1996 to 2004.
  • She won twenty medals, fifteen of which were gold.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize how long Mayumi Narita competed in the Paralympic Games?

options.name: A
options.content: During her career as a Paralympic swimmer, Mayumi Narita took home a total of twenty medals, fifteen of which were gold.

options.name: B
options.content: Swimming, a sport in which Mayumi Narita took home fifteen gold medals, has been an event at the Paralympic Games since 1960.

options.name: C
options.content: An accomplished Paralympian with multiple gold medal wins, Mayumi Narita competed as a swimmer from 1996 to 2004.

options.name: D
options.content: Cross-country skier Frank Höfle made his Paralympic debut in 1988, while swimmer Mayumi Narita made her debut in 1996.

questions.correct: An accomplished Paralympian with multiple gold medal wins, Mayumi Narita competed as a swimmer from 1996 to 2004.
